Ya mate, we all have a crystal ball that tells us when something will spike 100% overnight. If we all had the keys to knowing which stock would jump 100% the next day we’d all be billionaires and we sure as hell wouldn’t be sharing our secrets on reddit.

author: mulletator
body:
Those emotional charts are nothing new.  What you're failing to realize is the scope of the present economic situation.  This is not a normal recession.  I fully understand where you're coming from.  I usually invest that way too although I prefer individual stocks to ETFs and mutuals.   

The market is fucked man.  We already crashed and it's on life support right now from government stimulus.  Canada has already dumped $250 billion into stimulus and the US has put in at least $3 trillion.  That's all gone already, poof.  That is why we saw the recent bump in the market.  Nothing more.  Productivity is not picking up the way we hoped.  There are more shockers on the horizon.  Namely the US unemployment stimulus is ending soon and so is the mortgage holiday.

The world's economy is teetering right now.  There's more to the story than can be explained here.  What we are going to see is massive consolidation.  Big companies eating up small ones, the FAANG stocks are doing well right now but they rely on a healthy economy for people to buy their products.  It's hard to pay for Netflix if you lost your home.

You don't have to listen to me and this isn't my opinion either.  Take a look at the latest IMF reports for an impartial viewpoint on what is going on.  Things are bleak and that's accounting for everything that we already know.  Just look at the unrest in the last two weeks.  If any major stressors present themselves we are ultra-fucked.

The market is in full-on hope and dream mode with a vaccine already priced in.  Even if we had a vaccine today we'd still be screwed.  As long as we get a vaccine, maintain productivity, continue to innovate, and somehow reconcile the massive debt problems we will pull through this.  Those are big ifs.  

The world will survive I'm not saying this is the apocalypse but economic paradigm shifts have happened before.  China is already pushing out a new government-controlled cryptocurrency and that has powerful ramifications for the USD.  Check out this link (https://www.wired.co.uk/article/china-digital-currency-crypto).

It's ugly man.  I'm not just sharing my opinion here, the facts are all around us.  I wish this wasn't happening but it is.  The government stimulus kept the boat afloat and gave us time to get our affairs in order.  

I wish nothing more than to be wrong about all of this.  If you know something that I don't please share it with me and I'll jump right back into the market and DCA all day long.

Here are a couple more links:
https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2020-06-08/a-crash-in-the-dollar-is-coming
https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/fed-economist-argues-negative-interest-rates-needed-to-boost-us-economic-recovery
https://www.nsenergybusiness.com/features/fossil-fuel-profits-decline/
https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/06/3-keys-understanding-strangest-economy-ever/612373/
https://www.munknee.com/shift-from-u-s-dollar-as-world-reserve-currency-underway-what-will-this-mean-for-america/
https://theconversation.com/buckle-up-for-turbulence-why-a-global-debt-crisis-looks-very-hard-to-avoid-127260
https://theconversation.com/buckle-up-for-turbulence-why-a-global-debt-crisis-looks-very-hard-to-avoid-127260

author: HauntingRent
body:
In the short term, it doesn't matter at all. Nobody is getting rich based on Trump acting like Bozo the Clown every day.  People often *say* it will have an effect on stock market trading boards, because many people who trade stocks are themselves bozos who shouldn't be given the keys to their own bank accounts, let alone a trading account.

In the long term, it offers a chance at fixing the economy, and restoring international trade (on which much of our economy depends) to some semblance of a stable condition.  Right now, any business you invest in that depends on trade with China (in other words: **every stock you own**) is being whipsawed around based on how many farts the bozo-in-chief had that day. Electing anyone else will reduce volatility substantially.

author: Jsizzle19
body:
appreciate the clarification. the key really comes down to whether you want to be investing or gambling. You can get lucky, go on a nice streak and see your stocks rise a lot in a short period of time, but you’re playing with a house of cards.  you want your money to work for you. You may only have $1,300 now, but if you invest in a few, strong companies (profitable, strong balance sheets with positive free cash flow) or in an ETF / index fund where the stock prices will continue to increase over time, then each month or paycheck, set up a recurring deposit. Just like a 401k, you don’t want to touch the money. Just put it in there and try to forget about it (please note, there is nothing wrong with looking to
Rebalance your portfolio every so often) 

There are really 2 keys to investing: 1) always keep investing and 2) having the strength to stay in the game when the market drops 5-10%. 

You want to be in the game as long as possible. 
For example: if you invest $1,300 today with a $100 recurring monthly deposit and attain a 9% return (average annual return of the S&P 500), in 10 years you’ll have $22,050, in 20 years you’ll have $71,170, but in 30 years you’ll have $187,460. 

You want your investment earnings to keep compounding over time. The stock market should not be viewed as a get rich quick scheme

author: attirer
body:
As a new investor, you’re probably going to get better advice on r/PersonalFinanceCanada about getting started. There are good resources on the sidebar of that sub, search previous posts, and ask questions if you don’t see what you need.

Whether you focus on passive investing, dividend growth, value investing, or something else, you’ll achieve the greatest success by developing an informed strategy and sticking to it. The three keys are: [maximize your investments early](https://www.mrmoneymustache.com/2012/01/13/the-shockingly-simple-math-behind-early-retirement/) (the power of compound interest); stick to your strategy (“time in the market beats timing the market”); and keep your fees low. 

For passive investing, I suggest reading Andrew Hallam’s *Millionaire Teacher* (2nd ed) and John Robertson’s *The Value of Simple*. The archive of the [CCP blog](https://canadiancouchpotato.com/model-portfolios/) is a great resource, and more tips on the mechanics of passive investing are on the [CPM blog](https://www.canadianportfoliomanagerblog.com/model-etf-portfolios/). There are great videos on discrete passive investing topics on Ben Felix’s [YouTube Channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCDXTQ8nWmx_EhZ2v-kp7QxA) but I suggest reading the resources I’ve mentioned (particularly the two books) to have a better sense of what he’s talking about.

If passive investing isn’t for you, there are great resources on the sidebars (wikis, FAQs, book lists) of r/SecurityAnalysis, r/stocks, and r/investing.

My two cents: use your TFSA to buy shares in an all-in-one fund that tracks with your [risk profile](https://www.vanguardcanada.ca/individual/questionnaire.htm). Your greatest advantage is time, and investing early in a balanced all-in-one ETF could provided you with 20x-30x your investment by the time you retire.

author: lhatekale
body:
“Print” peals the silver voice of Jay.

You obey. 

You hold shift and your palms start sweating. Then you gingerly press “b”. Anticipation builds. You release the two keys. A flawless “B” appears on the terminal. Your heart races. It is finally time. Your eyes fervently turn to the key you know to be “r” even though the lettering on it had long ago been worn away. You voraciously hold it down as you crane your neck up to gaze back to the screen. 

“Brrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr” is printed in a pleasantly bland font on an equally bland background. You cannot contain it anymore and a euphoric moan escapes your lips, only to be echoed back at you and redoubled by the voices of your neighbors and indeed the entire American working class as they too all Print. You know it is but a fraction of divinity as compared to Jay as he sits locked upon his Printer Throne. He dedicates the entirety of his almighty JPower to convert the “Brr” signals into liquid currency to print the USA into safety while kindly reassuring the good people that all is well. You release the “r” key eight rapturous hours later, utterly spent.

author: ThisPomelo4
body:
>If I let my fingers wander idly over the keys of a typewriter it might happen that my screed made an intelligible sentence. If an army of monkeys were strumming on typewriters they might write all the books in the British Museum.   
>  
>Arthur Eddington

Imagine a drunk man on the sidewalk in front of a bar on Main Street at 10PM. Every second, he stumbles randomly -- either north or south with 50-50 probability -- moving 12 inches with each footstep. Your call option is like a bet that he will end up beyond Second Avenue, a couple of blocks to the north, before sunrise at 6AM the next day.

There are eight hours before daybreak, so he might just make it.

You drive past the bar at 3AM, long past closing time, and he is still in the same exact spot on the sidewalk. Five hours have passed, he has gone nowhere, and now he has less time to move (thus, fewer footsteps remaining) before sunrise. That's akin to theta decay.

At 3:30AM, you drive by again and notice that he has moved northward a little bit, but his footsteps are now 8 inches instead of the original 12 inches. Now it seems pretty unlikely that he will make it to Second Avenue. That's akin to vega.

author: StayClassynet
body:
I spent 10 years in ecomm selling personalization (web and email) and ecommerce platform software (ie. the website + shopping cart, inventory/promotion management etc.). My company was a partner of Avalara's for years.

I'm not familiar with AVLR's financials so I can't speak to how efficiently they are being run, but they are virtually guaranteed to continue their strong revenue growth. As it relates to the US ecommerce market, it's been the wild west since online shopping's inception. AVLR automates key tax processes & compliance by State, which as most would imagine differs significantly from one State to another and is a real pain in the ass for online retailers to keep up with changes/nuances/requirements/regulations. Up until the last few years, there hasn't been any governance around taxes for online shopping (even for large online retailers like Amazon). It sounds crazy, but a lot of online transactions haven't been taxed properly/correctly. That's starting to change and be monitored by Government, State by State and Avalara offers a great solution for this. With ecommerce adoption being further accelerated thanks to COVID, it stands to reason that an already growing industry (ecommerce) will continue to grow and AVLR stand to benefit nicely from this.

They are not the only players in this space (they do have lots of competition), but are easily one of the leading solution providers and have been for some time. One of the big keys to me for software like this is integration into other core ecommerce systems like payment processors/systems, ecommerce platform (ECP), order management (OMS), CRM/ERP/and more. AVLR do a really good job here.

author: Forty_Six_n_2
body:
Thorlabs is the Amazon of optics and photonics equipment but they're not publicly traded as far as I'm aware.

For lasers check out IPG and Coherent

For optics check out Gooch and Housego, Heraeus Quartz (optical glasses)

For detectors and cameras/beam profilers check out MKS instruments

Plenty of oscilloscope/ lab electronics companies too, agilent, keysight etc

These are just a few companies I know off the dome.

Would be interested to hear what your play is here!

author: Sir-Hops-A-Lot
body:
I knew man who was the last of the timber barons in Humboldt county, CA... He calls me one day and asks for a lift to a car dealership to pick up his new truck...a huge GMC diesel. I told him OK and he says "You have a sledgehammer, Brian?"

"No"

"A man needs a sledgehammer, Brian. I'll bring you one."

So he takes a cab from his house to my apartment, which is like 9 miles away. But, I'm a mile away from the dealership so he could have just gone the last like in the cab but, he was a lunatic so... You know.

And he had a sledgehammer. And we're about to leave and he says,  "Can I borrow your sledgehammer, Brian?"

"Sure"

" Thanks Brian"

And we go to the dealership. He pays for the truck, gets the keys and then takes the sledgehammer and hits the drivers side door. The hood and then the passenger side. Gives me "my"  sledgehammer back and says, "Now I don't have to worry about scratching it. "

And this wasn't even the most insanely logical thing I knew him to do.... There was one thing he did that will make me smile every I think about it until the day I die.

author: smurfguy
body:
I encourage everyone to look at crypto. It could be something big in the future. Never before have we had a system where anyone could create value and do it without the government stepping in. In traditional financial systems your value is controlled by the company in their own database. In crypto everyone involved gets ownership over their own part of the database if you control the keys yourself (holding on coinbase vs your own means). 

However, there are problems. One of the biggest now is scaling blockchains to handle more users. Right now both Bitcoin and Ethereum are struggling with how to deal with this. There are solutions, but they will take time to implement and they require general acceptance from the community to be useful. If you want to know what scaling problems mean to you just look at what it costs to send a transaction on the chains. 

There is a lot more to look at with cryptos, but I would say if you want the value to increase then the issue of scaling the blockchains would be the biggest risk to the value of your coins right now.

author: them_FIERCE
body:
Now let’s set aside the notion that stocks are allegedly suppose to trade at or anywhere near their valuations. 

DraftKings was able to make watching Soccer interesting to me. That is pure fucking wizardry. They hold the keys to a sports “betting” landscape that is practically untapped *globally*. Unlike casinos they have no risk exposure to outcome. They aren’t even classified as gambling in most countries because they make a legitimate argument that they are a game of skill not chance. So, no, tons of casinos are not just going to “make an app” and fart out profits. DraftKings has cornered the fantasy sports market, and if you haven’t looked at the financial trajectory of fantasy sports over the last 10 years...you done son. Pull back is def coming, so I hope your puts are reasonably placed because expecting the bottom to fall out just isn’t going to print.

author: Jsizzle19
body:
appreciate the clarification. the key really comes down to whether you want to be investing or gambling. You can get lucky, go on a nice streak and see your stocks rise a lot in a short period of time, but you’re playing with a house of cards.  you want your money to work for you. You may only have $1,300 now, but if you invest in a few, strong companies (profitable, strong balance sheets with positive free cash flow) or in an ETF / index fund where the stock prices will continue to increase over time, then each month or paycheck, set up a recurring deposit. Just like a 401k, you don’t want to touch the money. Just put it in there and try to forget about it (please note, there is nothing wrong with looking to
Rebalance your portfolio every so often) 

There are really 2 keys to investing: 1) always keep investing and 2) having the strength to stay in the game when the market drops 5-10%. 

You want to be in the game as long as possible. 
For example: if you invest $1,300 today with a $100 recurring monthly deposit and attain a 9% return (average annual return of the S&P 500), in 10 years you’ll have $22,050, in 20 years you’ll have $71,170, but in 30 years you’ll have $187,460. 

You want your investment earnings to keep compounding over time. The stock market should not be viewed as a get rich quick scheme

author: BrononymousEngineer
body:
You can do that too, and the data will be better, but it will be more work to actually get data from the brokerage APIs.  From what I've read the steps to connect to TDA are notoriously confusing, and I think for IBKR you have to have TWS running.  If I was actually going to pull data to trade on I'd get it from a brokerage.
Yahoo works for this purpose because it's educational and you don't need API keys -- it's available for everyone.

author: minos157
body: Yep, I just wish everyone would stop shitting on other peoples styles.  We're all here to make money.  If anyone ever caught me posting for a new person to just go balls deep on one pattern I'd quit investing because it won't happen.  Every time I join these posts to defend TA it is with the notion that discipline and emotion free trading are the keys to success, not TA, not FA, not style, not length of holdings.  Find a strategy that works for you, and stick to the plan.  Don't let others tell you you're doing it the wrong way.

It’s also pretty gay that Illinois only allows 10 replacement drivers licenses in a lifetime. I just turned 20 last week, and my new one will be number 4...

author: mulletator
body:
You mean this article?
https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/06/3-keys-understanding-strangest-economy-ever/612373/

That was a pretty good read.  No answers really but interesting.  I didn't realize that average income has gone up due to government stimulus and increase in unemployment benefits.

That doesn't bode well in my opinion.  That means that it will be harder to get low-income workers back to work.

That article seems to highlight that the entire economy is on life support from the FED.  Which is kind of my point.  How long can we keep this up?

author: Hotspur000
body:
Just my opinion, but some of the keys to being a day trader are:

1) Don't try to do too much. Focus on maybe 2 or 3 stocks that you think could move well in the day and go after them. If you're trying to do like 10 or 15 or something, you're splitting up your attention too much. This then directly leads to;

2) Don't be too greedy. If you earn some gains, take them. Prioritize ending the day up from where you started, even if it's by a smaller amount than you maybe would hope. I think a lot of day traders end up losing because they stay on a position too long, hoping for more, and then the floor falls out from under them.

And (again this is just personal opinion), don't play options. Options, to me, are just pure gambling and really stupid, because even if you take a chance on a stock and it doesn't pan out that day, well, at least, you own it, it's still an investment – six months later it might go up again and you can sell it them.

author: Lex_et_ordo
body: He is kind of right though. Zoom has 700+ engineers in China doing product development. They were caught routing security keys through data centers there.
